user_id.description: The auth user ID for a user.

gpt_file_format.description:
File format for files in conversations or GPTs.

If `url`, returned files follow the `ConversationFile` or `GPTFile` schema.

If `id`, returned files follow the `ConversationFileInfo` or `GPTFileInfo` schema.

conversation_file_format.description:
File format for files in conversations.

If `url`, returned files follow the `ConversationFile` schema.

If `id`, returned files follow the `ConversationFileInfo` schema.

project_file_format.description:
File format for files in Projects.

If `url`, returned files follow the `ProjectFile` schema.

If `id`, returned files follow the `ProjectFileInfo` schema.

last_id.description: The ID of the last object in the list.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more objects to list.

created_at.description: The Unix timestamp of the user creation time.

GPTConfig.description: A GPT configuration.  This describes a user-created version of the GPT, including instructions, description, name, and other details defining the GPT's behavior.

id.description: The ID of the configuration.  Uniquely identifies a GPT configuration.

categories.description: The list of categories that the builder chose to publish the GPT under.

created_at.description: The Unix timestamp of the configuration creation time.  This will not be provided for 3rd party GPTs.

instructions.description: Creator-provided instructions on how the GPT should behave.  This will not be provided for 3rd party GPTs.

version_author.description: The user that published this version of the GPT.

files.description: The list of files in the GPT configuration.  This will not be provided for 3rd party GPTs.  Note that this list includes a has_more attribute, but that attribute will always be false.  The list is complete.

tools.description: The list of tools in the GPT configuration.

created_at.description: The Unix timestamp of the tool creation time.

action_domain.description: The internet domain for the custom action. Only provided for `custom_action` tool type.

action_openapi_raw.description: The schema of the custom action. Only provided for `custom_action` tool type.

action_privacy_policy_url.description: The privacy policy url of the custom action. Only provided for `custom_action` tool type.

auth_type.description: The authentication type of the custom action. Only provided for `custom_action` tool type.

id.description: The ID of the file.

created_at.description: The Unix timestamp of the file creation time.

download_url.description: The URL to download the file.  The URL expires after 1 hour.  If the file has expired, the `created_at` and `download_url` will be `null`.

id.description: The ID of the file.
The auth user ID of the version author.

email.description: The email address of the version author.

id.description: The ID of the file.

user_id.description: The auth user ID of the user who owns the file.

tool_name.description: The name of the tool used to generate the message, if applicable.  Unsupported tools will have a null value.

MessageContent.description: The content of the message. This value is null for messages generated through unsupported tools.

type.description: The type of the message content.

value.description: The value of the message content.

annotations.description: The list of annotations in the message content.

urls.description: The list of URLs in the annotation.

id.description: The ID of the message.

parent_id.description: The ID of the parent message.

gpt_id.description: The ID of the GPT used to generate the message, if applicable.  If the message was generated by a default model (not a custom GPT), this will be `null`.

project_id.description: The ID of the project used to generate the message, if applicable.  If the message was generated by a default model (not a custom GPT), this will be `null`.

id.description: The ID of the conversation.

created_at.description: The Unix timestamp of the conversation creation time.

last_active_at.description:
The Unix timestamp of the last conversation activity.
This is updated when one of the following actions occur:

1. A message is added to the conversation.
2. A title is automatically generated for the conversation.

*Note: The ordering of conversations based on update time does not necessarily match `last_active_at`.
Conversations can be updated without being active,
such as when migrated from a personal workspace.
At this time, last update time is not exposed as a field.*

messages.description: The list of messages in the conversation.

created_at.description: The Unix timestamp of the GPT creation time.  This is not provided for 3rd party GPTs.

owner_id.description: The auth user ID of the GPT owner.  This is not provided for 3rd party GPTs.

owner_email.description: The email of the GPT owner.  This is not provided for 3rd party GPTs.

builder_name.description: The GPT builder name as displayed on ChatGPT.

sharing.description: The sharing level of the GPT.  This is not provided for 3rd party GPTs.

can_read.description: Indicates whether the sharing recipient can chat with the GPT.

can_view_config.description: Indicates whether the sharing recipient can view the configurations of the GPT.

can_write.description: Indicates whether the sharing recipient can edit the GPT.

items.description: A user that a GPT is shared with.

id.description: The auth user ID of the recipient.

can_read.description: Indicates whether the sharing recipient can chat with the GPT.

can_view_config.description: Indicates whether the sharing recipient can view the configurations of the GPT.

can_write.description: Indicates whether the sharing recipient can edit the GPT.

id.description: The auth user ID of the user who owns the memory.
The ID of the memory context.  Note that this could be a user ID if it refers to the user's primary memory context.
The ID of the memory entry.

content.description: The content of the memory entry.

updated_at.description: The Unix timestamp of the memory entry update time.

textdoc_type.description: The type of the canvas document.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more canvases to list.

last_id.description: The ID of the last recording in the list.

TranscriptDownloadResponse.description: A response containing the recording transcript and optional summary.

version.description: The version of the response schema.

id.description: The unique automation identifier.

is_enabled.description: Indicates if the automation is enabled.

data.description: The list of files in the Project configuration.

action_domain.description: The internet domain for the custom action (only if `custom_action`).

action_openapi_raw.description: The schema for the custom action (only if `custom_action`).

data.description: The list of tools in the Project configuration.

ProjectConfig.description: A Project configuration. This describes a user-created version of a Project.

categories.description: The list of categories that the builder chose to publish the Project under.

id.description: Unique identifier for a Codex execution environment.

Command(s) used to configure the environment container before first run.

url.description: HTTPS or SSH URL of the repository.

get.description:
Retrieve conversations from a workspace, ordered by last update time.

### Pagination
- Results are paginated using the `after` parameter to fetch subsequent pages.
- Page size may vary due to internal factors; fewer results do not imply the end of available data.
- Ensure deduplication of messages using `messageID` during pagination, as conversations may appear multiple times if updated between API calls.

> **Note**: Conversation order by update time may differ from the value in `last_active_at`. Conversations might be updated without direct activity, for instance, when migrated from a personal workspace. Currently, the actual update timestamp isn't exposed as an API field.

### Payload Size
- Typical conversation size varies greatly, potentially ranging from KBs to ~2MB or more multiply that by every conversation you request.
- Treat responses as potentially large files or very long strings, depending on your database schema.
- Conversation size may increase further over time as the underlying data models evolve.
- Enabling compression at your database or storage layer is strongly recommended.

The Compliance API does not strictly enforce a maximum payload size for responses. Practical limitations such as network timeouts or client-side capacity constraints might cause failed responses.

Generally, each conversation's payload is approximately **2MB**, subject to change, meaning total payload size can become large depending on how many conversations are requested.

### Recommendations for Handling Large Payloads
- Utilize the `limit` parameter to paginate data effectively, our service doesn't have issues with exporting a lot of conversations, but some users might.
- Reduce `limit` values when encountering issues with payload size, for example, lowering from `limit=100` to `limit=50` especially if your client is RAM-limited.
- If you have issues, you can implement an exponential back-off strategy to dynamically manage your `limit` parameter based on request successes or failures, especially under network limitations or after encountering rate-limit errors (`HTTP 429`).

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: since_timestamp
parameters.description:
When present, results will be limited to conversations last updated at or later than the provided Unix timestamp.

Cannot be used together with `after`. Providing both parameters results in an error.

*Note: The filtering of conversations based on update time does not necessarily match `last_active_at`.
Conversations can be updated without being active,
such as when migrated from a personal workspace.
At this time, last update time is not exposed as a field.*

parameters.name: after
parameters.description:
The previous conversation ID from which to fetch the next page of conversations.
The endpoint will return the next conversations that would come after the conversation identified by `after`.

Cannot be used together with `since_timestamp`. Providing both parameters results in an error.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The number of conversations to list.  The maximum number of conversations that can be returned is 500.  The default is 500.

parameters.name: users
parameters.description:
If specified, only list conversations for these users.
Can be specified multiple times.

Example:

```
/compliance/workspaces/{workspace_id}/conversations?after=1234&users=user-1&users=user-2&users=user-3
```

Must be less than 100 total users.

404.description: An identifying parameter was not found (`workspace_id`, etc.).

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 50 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

delete.description:
This deletes the conversation title, messages, files, and shared links from the workspace.
The conversation history pane will continue to list a placeholder with the title "(Removed by your admin)"
and ordered based on the last updated date of the deleted conversation. Users cannot interact with this placeholder.
The placeholder will expire (and be removed from the history pane) within 30 days of conversation deletion.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: conversation_id
parameters.description: The ID of the conversation to delete.

404.description: The conversation or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

get.description:
List workspace GPTs. This API can return any *live* workspace GPT, regardless of sharing level.
This will not list 3rd party GPTs, even those that are approved for use in the workspace.
It will not return *draft* GPTs.  A draft GPT is one where the creator may have added configurations
but has not clicked `Create`.
Note: 'community builder' is the default placeholder builder_name for hidden names or not verified
[builder profiles](https://help.openai.com/en/articles/8798878-building-and-publishing-a-gpt);
you can use the owner_id or email to find the user.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description:
The previous GPT ID from which to fetch the next page of GPTs.  The endpoint will return
the next GPTs that would come after the GPT identified by `after`.  Used for pagination.
If `after` is not provided, the first page of GPTs is returned.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
The maximum number of GPTs to list.  The default is 20.  Note that this may return fewer
than the provided `limit`.  Use the `has_more` response field to determine if there are
more GPTs to list.

404.description: An identifying parameter was not found (`workspace_id`, etc.).

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 50 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

get.description:
Get a GPT by ID.  If the request specifies a 3rd party GPT, this will only succeed if the GPT
is published publicly.  For 3rd party GPTs, the returned data will only contain publicly available
information.  This API can return any *live* workspace GPT, regardless of sharing level.
It will not return *draft* GPTs.  A draft GPT is one where the creator may have added configurations
but has not clicked `Create`.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: gpt_id
parameters.description: The ID of the GPT to retrieve.

404.description: The GPT or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

delete.description:
This deletes the GPT from the workspace, including all associated files; it does not delete all Conversations which used the GPT.
In the case where the files in a deleted GPT are referenced by another GPT, the files are not deleted.
This can happen, for example, if GPT A is created with files, then GPT B is created as a copy of GPT A.
For immediate deletion of GPT files, use the dedicated endpoint.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: gpt_id
parameters.description: The ID of the GPT to delete.

404.description: The GPT or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

The previous configuration ID from which to fetch the next page of configurations.

parameters.name: limit

404.description: The file is not found for GPTs in this workspace.

410.description: The file has expired, and the content is no longer available.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per api key.

delete.description:
This deletes the GPT file from the workspace. The file reference is also deleted from all
GPTs in the workspace. This applies only to files uploaded during GPT creation.
Files generated during a conversation with a custom GPT should use the user-owned file deletion
endpoint. After the file is deleted, it is replaced with a virtual placeholder file with the
title "(Removed by your admin)" and no content.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: gpt_id
parameters.description: The ID of the GPT.

parameters.name: file_id
parameters.description: The ID of the file to delete.

404.description: The GPT, file, or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per api key.

Used for pagination.  If `after` is not provided, the first page of shared users is returned.

404.description: The GPT or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 50 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

delete.description:
This removes access to the GPT for all share recipients (users, groups, etc.). The GPT is
still available for use by the owner. This does not block the owner from sharing the GPT
again in the future.

parameters.description: The ID of the conversation to fetch the file from. Required for audio and video files

307.description: This API endpoint issues a 307 redirect to a file download URL specified in the Location header. The provided URL will serve the file for download.

404.description: The file is not found for the requested workspace user.

410.description: The file has expired, and the content is no longer available.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per api key.

delete.description:
This deletes the specified user-owned file from the workspace. Any conversations that reference this
continue to reference the file ID, but the file is no longer available for download or
retrieval. No conversation messages are changed when this file is deleted. This applies to
both uploaded and generated files, including files that are generated in a conversation with
a custom GPT.

Please note that the model may have chosen to insert part of the file into
the context of a conversation; these stuffed snippets will NOT be deleted.
You can discover such conversations using the List Conversations Endpoint,
and searching for usages of the myfiles_browser GPT tool.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user who uploaded the file.

parameters.name: file_id
parameters.description: The ID of the file to delete.

parameters.name: conversation_id
parameters.description: The ID of the conversation to delete the file from. Required for audio and video files

404.description: The user, file, or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

get.description:
List workspace Projects. This API can return any *live* workspace Project, regardless of sharing level.
It will not return *draft* Projects.  A draft Project is one where the creator may have added configurations
but has not clicked `Create`.

The previous Project ID from which to fetch the next page of Projects.
The endpoint will return the next Projects that would come after the Project identified by `after`.
Used for pagination.  If `after` is not provided, the first page of Projects is returned.

parameters.name: limit

The maximum number of Projects to list.  The default is 20.
Note that this may return fewer than the provided `limit`.
Use the `has_more` response field to determine if there are more Projects to list.

It will not return *draft* Projects.

parameters.description: The ID of the file to fetch.

307.description: This API endpoint issues a 307 redirect to a file download URL specified in the Location header. The provided URL will serve the file for download.

404.description: The file is not found for Projects in this workspace.

410.description: The file has expired, and the content is no longer available.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per api key.

delete.description:
This deletes the Project file from the workspace. The file reference is also deleted from all
Projects in the workspace. This applies only to files uploaded during Project creation.
Files generated during a conversation with a custom Project should use the user-owned file deletion
endpoint. After the file is deleted, it is replaced with a virtual placeholder file with the
title "(Removed by your admin)" and no content.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: project_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Project.

parameters.name: file_id
parameters.description: The ID of the file to delete.

404.description: The Project, file, or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

get.description: Lists directly shared users for the Project in ascending order of the `user_id`.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: project_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Project.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description:
The previous user ID from which to fetch the next page of shared users.
The endpoint will return the next shared users that would come after the user identified by `after`.
Used for pagination.
If `after` is not provided, the first page of shared users is returned.

200.description: A list of Project shared users.

last_id.description: The auth user ID of the last user in the list.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more shared users to list.

data.description: The shared users for this Project.

404.description: The Project or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 50 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

delete.description:
This removes access to the Project for all share recipients (users, groups, etc.). The Project is
still available for use by the owner. This does not block the owner from sharing the Project
again in the future.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: project_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Project.

404.description: The Project or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.  This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per endpoint per api key.

get.description: Retrieves a paginated list of automations for the specified workspace user. You can filter by a Unix timestamp (since_timestamp) or use the `after` parameter to paginate through results.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The workspace ID.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description: The previous automation ID from which to fetch the next page of automations.  The endpoint will return the next automations that would come after the automation identified by `after`.  Used for pagination. If `after` is not provided, the first page of automations is returned.

parameters.name: since_timestamp
parameters.description: When specified, only list automations updated after the given Unix timestamp. Can't set when `after` is already provided.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of automations to return. Must be between 1 and 100.

has_more.description: Indicates if more automations are available for pagination.

400.description: Bad Request  invalid or conflicting parameters.

404.description: Workspace or user not found.

429.description: Too Many Requests  rate limit exceeded.

get.description: List recordings for the specified workspace user.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of recordings to list. Default is 10.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: The pagination cursor from a previous response.

404.description: The user or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests. This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per API key.

get.description: Download the transcript for a recording. Optionally include the summary.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user who created the recording.

parameters.name: recording_id
parameters.description: The ID of the recording.

parameters.name: include_summary
parameters.description: Whether to include the summary.

404.description: The recording was not found.

delete.description: Deletes the specified recording from the workspace.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user who created the recording.

parameters.name: recording_id
parameters.description: The ID of the recording to delete.

404.description: The recording was not found.

429.description: Too many requests. This endpoint is rate limited to 100 requests per minute per API key.

delete.description: Deletes the specified automation for the workspace user. This will delete the automation and stop future scheduled runs.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The workspace ID.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user.

parameters.name: automation_id
parameters.description: The ID of the automation to delete.

404.description: Automation not found.

429.description: Too Many Requests  rate limit exceeded.

get.description: Retrieves a single Codex codeexecution task by ID.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: task_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Codex task to retrieve.

404.description: The Codex task or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.This endpoint is ratelimited to 100 requests per minute per API key.

delete.description:
Deletes a Codex codeexecution task from the workspace.
This also deletes any associated execution artifacts.
Only enterprise admins with the **compliance_export:delete** scope can perform this action.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: task_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Codex task to delete.

404.description: The Codex task or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.This endpoint is ratelimited to 100 requests per minute per API key.

get.description: Retrieves a single Codex execution environment by ID.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: environment_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Codex environment to retrieve.

404.description: The Codex environment or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.This endpoint is ratelimited to 100 requests per minute per API key.

delete.description: Deletes a Codex execution environment from the workspace, including all state stored within the environment.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: environment_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Codex environment to delete.

404.description: The Codex environment or workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.This endpoint is ratelimited to 100 requests per minute per API key.

get.description:
Lists Codex execution environments that belong to the workspace.
Results are returned in descending order of creation time.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description:
The ID of the last environment from the previous page.
Results start **after** this ID (cursorbased pagination).

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Maximum number of environments to return (default and max = 30).

404.description: The workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.This endpoint is ratelimited to 50 requests per minute per API key.

get.description:
Lists Codex codeexecution tasks that belong to the workspace in
descending order of `updated_at`.

parameters.name: workspace_id
parameters.description: The ID of the workspace.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
Cursor that marks the starting point for the next page of results.
Use the `cursor` field from the previous response.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Maximum number of tasks to return (default and max = 30).

cursor.description: Cursor for fetching the next page of results.

404.description: The workspace was not found.

429.description: Too many requests.This endpoint is ratelimited to 100 requests per minute per API key.

tags.name: Introduction
tags.description:
This API allows ChatGPT Enterprise administrators to observe and remove data from their ChatGPT Enterprise workspaces. It is intended for compliance, security, and data privacy use.  The delete endpoints are designed for spot deletion of data, not bulk deletion.  The get endpoints provide time-indexed access to ChatGPT Enterprise data.  Administrators can use it to retrieve this data for archival or Data Loss Prevention purposes as part of a compliance or security program.

This API is designed for regularly downloading data diffs to synchronize an offline database for data compliance, rather than mass export. The initial data sync will take longer, but subsequent syncs will be faster as only the diffs need to be downloaded.  The API is rate limited to prevent abuse.

ChatGPT conversations can grow over time as the user continues chatting in a conversation.  This API always returns the latest stored version of the conversation.  ChatGPT Enterprise Administrators can choose to store all versions that they retrieve, or only the latest, depending on the use case.

*Note:* ChatGPT is a nascent product that will likely be updated significantly and frequently.  OpenAI will make every effort to provide as much notice as possible when this happens.  We encourage developers to build for flexibility to adapt to future changes.

### Authentication
1. Owners can generate an API key in the [OpenAI API Platform Portal](https://platform.openai.com/api-keys).
   Note that the correct Organization must be selected when creating a key, corresponding to the
   administered workspace.  Do not select the owner's personal organization.
2. Create a new API key:
    - Settings:  Default Project | All Permissions
    - Note that this must be a new key.  Once the Compliance API scopes are granted, all other
      scopes are revoked.
    - Reminder:  This key can only be viewed/copied once.  Store it securely.
3. Send an email to [support@openai.com](mailto:support@openai.com) with
   (1) the last 4 digits of the API key,
   (2) the Key Name,
   (3) the Created By Name, and
   (4) the requested scope (`read`, `delete` or both).
4. Our team will verify the key and grant the requested Compliance API scopes.
5. Administrators may now use this key or pass it to a partner for use with the Compliance API.
6. Remember the base url is `https://api.chatgpt.com/v1/` for all requests below.

### Retention
Deleted data is not recoverable. This API does not provide the capability for deleting any data
logged for audit or security within OpenAI. All authenticated requests to this API are logged
for security and compliance purposes. When an item is deleted using this API, it is also removed
from all internal search and retrieval indexes.  Data is retained internally for no greater than
30 days following a deletion request.

#### **Messages**
There are several ways messages can be edited/deleted in ChatGPT:
- Workspace setting: Admins can set a retention setting for the entire workspace (minimum 90d).
  Messages will be deleted N days after the last edit to the conversation (N set by Admins)
  on a going forward basis.
- User delete conversation: These conversations will still be available via this API for up to 30d
  but not visible to the user.
- User edit/delete message: These conversations will be shown via the API in the conversation tree
  subject to the retention settings above

#### **Files**
There are 4 different file retentions within ChatGPT:
- GPT & Project Files: Files uploaded to GPTs/Projects are retained indefinitely since new conversations require them.
- Chat Uploaded Files: Files uploaded by users are held temporarily (48hrs)
- Generated Files: Files generated by ChatGPT (ie DALLE) are held based on the workspace's
  retention setting

### File URL Expiration
File URLs are generated each time the Compliance API is polled.
- Files can be downloaded from these URLs, and for security reasons, they have an expiry of 1 hour.
- For direct requests to fetch file contents, the redirect contains an ephemeral download URL which expires after 5 minutes.
- Thus, if files are needed for compliance purposes, messages should be polled regularly (before their retention setting) and then downloaded soon after polling before the URL expires.

### Implementation Tips
Coding tip:
- You can download the OpenAI Compliance Spec as a JSON file from the top of this page.
- Using the JSON Spec File, you can ask ChatGPT to generate some starter code for youusing a reasoning model often yields the best results.
- There are also various open source projects available (such as OpenAPI Gen, Swagger Autogen, and others) that have been developed by the community.
- As always, we can't promise the accuracy of 3rd-party tools or auto-generated code, so always double-check the values returned are as expected .

```
# You should probably autogen or get ChatGPT to help as mentioned above, but here's some examples.
#  Curl (no pagination) Example for Projects
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer {sk-proj-KEY-HERE}" "https://api.chatgpt.com/v1/compliance/workspaces/{INPUT_WORKSPACE_HERE}/projects"

#  Python Basic (no pagination) for Projects
import requests
url = "https://api.chatgpt.com/v1/compliance/workspaces/{INPUT_WORKSPACE_HERE}/projects"
headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {sk-proj-KEY-HERE}"}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
# Add code to loop until has_more is false, using after to get the next page of projects
# If 429/rate limit, slow down and try again.
```

Common Mistakes:
- Make sure to use "has_more" & "after"/"since_timestamp" or similar pagination logic to page through the list of items.
- Make sure to use either `after` or `since_timestamp`. Including both parameters will result in an error.
- If you hit the API too fast, you may get a 429 rate-limit error. Just slow down and try again.
- Using `api.openai.com` instead of `api.chatgpt.com` can cause a 404 error.

tags.name: Users
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace user data.

tags.name: Conversations
tags.description:
Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace conversations.

*Common Tools*
- **Canvases** (*The popout window in a conversation*) are sometimes related to conversations, but not technically required; so this should be kept in mind when exporting data there is a canvas admin endpoint as well. See `Canvases` Tab for details.
- **Deep Research** [Filter by tool_name = 'deep_research' to find the response to the user] when used will add its final user-facing response to the conversation it was initiated from once completed, and there will also be a new background conversation(s) created (hidden from the user, but visible to you) that contains the user's prompt as well as OpenAI's deep research template prompt which is sent to the background worker.
    In the conversation API the background and primary conversation will be also listed under the user's ID.
-  Example Flow of Deep Research: (Deep Research Request -> Starts Background Conversation with Prompt [5-30 minute wait] -> Adds Response to User's Conversation). Background conversations typically have identical opening messages in their prompts, though this may evolve over time as we refine the prompt.

tags.name: Canvases
tags.description:
Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace canvases.
- Note, Canvases (*The popout window in a conversation*) are sometimes related to conversations, but not technically required; so this should be kept in mind when exporting data.

tags.name: GPTs
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace GPTs. **Note, they have a very similar structure to Projects**; this should help with implementation.

tags.name: Projects
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace Projects. **Note, they have a very similar structure to GPTs**; this should help with implementation. Initially, they were built on top of GPTs, but in the future, they might have additional features.

tags.name: Memories
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace Memories.

tags.name: Automations
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace Automations.

tags.name: Codex Tasks
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace Codex tasks.

tags.name: Codex Environments
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace Codex environments.

tags.name: Recordings
tags.description: Endpoints for exporting and spot-deleting ChatGPT Enterprise workspace recordings.

tags.name: Version History
tags.description:
### 1.1.5
*2025-06-10*
- Added compliance API support for recording endpoints.

### 1.1.4
*2025-05-16*
- Added compliance API support for Codex endpoints.

### 1.1.3
*2025-03-18*
- Added compliance API support for Automations endpoints.

### 1.1.2
- Added Deep Research as an explicit tool name 'deep_research' to the Conversation API. Based on user feedback, instead of looking for the prompt in the message history, you can now look for the tool name.

### 1.1.1
*2025-02-18*
- Added version author to GPT Configurations endpoint.
- Added notes for Deep Research, but it uses the Conversation API. So no extra work should be needed for support.

### 1.1.0
*2025-01-15*
- Added Project endpoints.

*2024-12-17*
- Added Canvas Endpoints.

*2024-06-24*
- Added Memory Endpoints.

*2024-06-11*
- Created endpoints for exporting and deleting memories. Also created delete endpoints for
  User Files, GPT Files, GPTs, and Conversations.

### [1.0.0](https://docs.google.com/document/d/157SnVe5dPvHSvC67hwrberxLC-TcM34DFspO4eSEjnQ)
*2024-04-30*

Initial version of the Enterprise Compliance API, including only data export endpoints for conversations, GPTs,
GPT Configurations, and Workspace Users.
